projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A peculiar PROGNOSTICATION Astrologically predicted according to Art: VVhether, or No, His Majestie Shall suffer Death this present Yeere 1649.
The possibility thereof discussed and divulged, By William Lilly, Student in Astrologie.

figure.head: C R
figure.q: HONI SOIT QVI MAL Y PENSE

div.head: A peculiar Prognosticrtion Astrologically predictep according to art.
div.p: SI Saturnus fuerit in Geminis vel ejus triplicitate, significat quod qu • cquid significaverit sive bonum sit illud significatum sive maluus, ut plurimum apparebit occidentalibus (saith Bonatus) if Saturne be in Gemini or in the ayery triplicity, whether then he signifie good or ill, for the most part his significations appear Westward, from hence will arise thus much, that what is materially signified from Saturn, will shew it selfe in the West part of England, as in relation to the whole Kingdome; but as to London it points the West parts thereof, and the adj • cent lying from the body of the City; it is very probable the most considerabln actions of this quarter, will significantly manifest themselves in London: Accident hominibus infirmitates de frigido, &c. The people will be subject to Agues and such like infirmities as proceed from cold and dry causes; men will be contentious given to lying, from whence it may be feared there will arise some bloodshed, but God may and I hope will divert effusion of blood? So that insteed of blood, we may onely quarrell in words or with our pens, for indeed I doe not see that warre or effusion of blood can positively happen, Tumults and motions, heart-burnings, distemped mutterings and grumblings may appear; my meaning still is, that I doe not conceive the City sh • ll receive any prejudice by the souldiery, Deus avertat.

We must expect the exile, vanishment, imprisonment or death of some great King or Prince, shedding of blood amongst the common people, and greater persons; we must expect discords, mutuall dissimulations: the motions of a great Army, wars murthers, firing of houses, theeves plundering, depopulations, miscarriage of women with child, sharp fevers, and universall sicknesse amongst men, by reason there will be a pestile • ayre, also an admirable change or mutation in the Common-Wealth; being forewarnd me thinks some might be forearmd, if the Parliament of England and Army invite Prince Charles home, and he refuse (as God forbid he should,) great things will assuredly be put in execution and may prove very fatall to the Prince, and so may produce that excellent mutation spoken of, and it were well advised if such counsell were given to the Duke of York: (Cavere stamma ferro igne) assuredly the great Eclipses this year, those which lately preceded and are subsequent, mutationes institutionum, legum sectarumque, & senecta casus seu mortem senioribus significant, are the messengers of the alterations of former Lawes and institutions and sects, the death of some old Matron Queen or noble woman, and also of many ancient men.

The nobility, the rich and great ones about these times are like to be sick by reason of ill and unwholsome blasts of wind, anglicè the breath of the people, cry for vengeance upon them, and by reason of earthquakes and unsavory fumosities of the earth, and by reason of warre and complaints betwixt the rich man, and the poore man: the hatred of the people begins sooner against their Superiors then otherwise it would, and coutinues more fiercely: many of quality will be committed, authority finding how much they have been cheated and couzned by Members of
their own; It is for money, and robbing the Common-Wealth that many have the sentence of condemnation.

Absolutely the souldier or sword is rampart this year, or either gives Lawes or straines hard for it, to settle the Kingdome in a very judicious posture, not wronging the civill Magistrate or the just Lawes of the Kingdome, but regulates their exorbitancies; let no mans heart faile, the work of God is going forward.

Doubtlesse the materiall effects of the great Eclipse hapning this yeare, which shall concern England, they will principally be effected in London and Westminster, this I mean as unto the Body politique. Saturnus fer t mal cum tarditate, Mars verò subitò, & ideo Mars reputatur deterior Saturno in nocendo; former treasons acted against the King, Parliament and Army, are now strictly inquired after, viz. what Peer or Nobleman joyned with the Scots, and brought in that numerous Army of cowards; what Members of the House of Commons had clandestine consultations with the Scots Commissioners in Lincolns Inne Fields, and Covent Garden, and it will be inquired what Citizens promised the Scots Armes and money, and help away with part of the Navie, sent their servants to Colchester against the Lord Fairfax. And who were so busie and active in so of't disturbing the Parliament with peremptory Petitions, now these are found out and receive punishment, who have retarded the Armies pay and money, of purpose to destroy them and cut the throats of all those honest soules, who conscientiously ingaged for the Kingdomes good, and no intention (I hope) to destroy Monarchy as is falsly suggested, but to regulate it and obtain those just rights we were borne unto: the most materiall thing signified by this Eclipse, is a strict questioning
and bringing to severe punishment, English Traytors that for these two yeares last past have disturbed the whole Kingdome, inforced the Parliament, &c. Fines and mulcts of money in a large measure are foreseen from hence to be levied out of the estates of Mallefactors, but some of principall quality I feare must follow the example of their fellowes in mischief, and become either heedlesse or die otherwise, according to the quality of their Oaths and offence: This year emergent occasions will rise in Ireland, and that Kingdome doth swell; nor is it evident unto me▪ but that this year, the most noble house of Austria will again be near unto some domestick broiles, I mean the Emperor of Germany may greatly distrust some secret plottings to disturb his little quiet, the person of the King of Spain is much subject to receive prejudice by this Eclipse; but thou noble branch of the Austrian house be sure it is the fore-runner of sedition, and some treacherous designe against thy happinesse; I fear a mutiny of thy Subjects, during the effects of this Eclipse.

The industrious Venetian is much concerned in this Eclipse, but alas there is a configuration
this yeare will assuredly prove ominous unto them, yet providence miraculously, even beyond admiration at the time of the action much lessen the will.

Worthy men, make peace with the seditious Turk; for indeed I conceive this yeare Constantinople will be much hindered by the head strong Janisaries: and now I mention France, wherein J find as much willingnesse in the people to rise and follow our steps in England, as ever any were to eat, when pittifully hungry the viall of wrath is preparing for that Kingdome.

What shall I write of the wary Scot, whose invasion deceived our judgement the last year, this Eclipse doth demonstrate a second failing in thee or some of HAMILTONS faction do intend further to disturb thy welfare and ours, thou beginnest about these times to totter and shake, by reason of some great hopes thou hast, not from us, but the approach of a great person into thy Kingdome, if providence contradict it not; make not thy self the seat of endlesse warr, or the scorn or Nations by reason of treachery: Col. JON • S thou man of honour, now have thou care of our English; it seemes some motion of our Armies
or stragling Brigadoes appeare Southward or Eastward; Lord God, what, honourable things wouldst thou have perform'd, if supplies had seconded either thy valor or fortune.

Every sign is ascending, the times are either disturbed with bloodshed and warre, or else with execution of justice upon turbulent spirits; were not our spirits miraculously supported these times, the common people will dispair and mistrust Gods providence: we are infinite full of counsell, those grand ones having but untoward intelligence from our friends in Scotland, nor very pleasing news from Ireland, I think this year our divisions would invite all the world to fool us or slight us; many showers will be, and what ever danger was formerly threatned wil be much lessened by the meanest position, though retrograde, it is said by some: Erit bellum licet medicum, & tristabitur Rex illius regionis: Some little war or scuffling to no purpose, she signifies, but it produces sorrow to the King of that Region, and who is King of Scotland we all know; she points out the same things to the Committe • of Estates sitting there, England is ours, and we will hold it, nor from this day shall a Scot ever come in our Nation without our consent and love, possesse a cottage or a poore farme; providence hath not assigned our earth to any but English, so long as the earth it selfe and men in it continue.

This year there will be much robbing on the dry Land, and great store of Pyracies upon the Seas; Mars prenotes the ruines or demolishing of very ancient foundations or buildings; dissimulation and fraud amongst the Clergy, stirring up the multitude to sedition and tumults; Da nobis pacem Domine.
